item.title: Cement, Wood & Tin: Fund 15 Cambodian Houses
item.description:
This is a video I collaborated on with several forPEACE volunteers for a crowd funding campaign on Generosity.com.

Why do I volunteer and donate?

Initially I volunteered because that is what good Christians do. While I still think there is truth in that, I volunteer now because I know life is not fair. Going through hard things and caring about people has made me more empathetic. I am not a Bill Gates with millions to spare, but I do my best to reach for my goals and help others along my way reach for theirs.

Why do I volunteer with forPEACE?

When I first met the founder, I had ideas and a strong case of wanderlust—thirsty to understand the world outside my bubble and help where I could. The reason I still volunteer is that the people I have met are intelligent with good hearts, working grassroots to create positive change in lives.

Since 1997, forPEACE has partnered with Tabitha Cambodia to fund:
  • wells and ponds
  • livestock
  • agriculture and small cottage industry business development houses
Tabitha focuses on community development through an integrated Savings Program. The purpose of this program is to teach families to save a small amount each week so that they can, over time, attain food security, send their children to school, and build adequate housing.

However, approximately 1 in 10 families in a community need extra help. For these families, forPEACE recruits international volunteers to assist in house building for one week. Our teams pay for their own travel and in-country expenses. Most of them also donate towards the building materials.

The cost of one house, which includes a personal well, is $1500. Currently we build 6 houses during our week in Cambodia. However, we have the capacity and readiness to build 15—provided that we raise the funds for the additional building materials.

To make a donation visit:

https://www.generosity.com/volunteer-fundraising/cement-wood-tin-fund-15-cambodian-houses

item.title: Anywhere You Go – NERVO feat. Timmy Trumpet Remix
item.description:
I put together this ethereal mix with an eerie edge for a Splice remix contest. I kept the atmospheric vibe of the Nervo original, just restructured it a bit and played with layers, entrances and timing—like changing the intro and outro, shifting Timmy’s fantastic trumpet serenade off the down beat (1:40), and adding rhythmic flavor to percussive elements as they re-enter after the music reduces to a sonar-like ping (2:40).

I also added synths throughout for sound effects, like data and warp speed, and used them to densify the atmosphere—and I threw in a few more vocals and lyrics for variety.

item.title: Cheers to 2016!
item.description:
This video is the result of experimenting with editing together 360 and HD videos from a trip to Australia and New Zealand — a dream trip I started planning in elementary school.

Favorite moments:

  • dolphins at 2:16
  • scuba diving at 4:30—complete with a shark and turtle siting!

item.title: The Playful Wonderland Behind Great Inventions
item.description:
"Necessity isn't always the mother of invention. The playful state of mind is fundamentally exploritory. Seeking out new possibilities in the world around us."

I love this TED talk by Steve Johnson, a writer examining the intersection of science, technology and personal experience. He intriguingly reframes the motivation behind inventions from bone flutes to organs, musical keyboards, the first typewriter (the writing harpsihord), and programmable music boxes and looms.


Necessity is the mother of invention, right? Well, not always. Steven Johnson shows us how some of the most transformative ideas and technologies, like the computer, didn't emerge out of necessity at all but instead from the strange delight of play. Share this captivating, illustrated exploration of the history of invention. Turns out, you'll find the future wherever people are having the most fun.

item.title: How to take and share a 360° photo
item.description:
A video tutorial demonstrating how to take and share a 360° photo with the Ricoh Theta SC camera and app.




360° Photo Example

A behind-the-scenes theta tutorial photo #MoreThanCode #HackReactor #theta360 - Spherical Image - RICOH THETA

If you want to learn more about the camera, you can check it out here.
https://theta360.com/en/

If you are curious, yes, they have API and SDK docs.
https://developers.theta360.com/en/docs/

item.title: A Boy and His Dream
item.description:
I found this node wrapper for the jp2a CLI tool and just had to make something with it, so here is an ASCII art music video to go with the new song.



LYRICS:

I hear it in your voice
I see it in your eyes
If they got any brighter
It would look like a sunrise
How could I say anything but, "that's great"
With that smile on your face

But why does it still hurt
Why do I care
Why do I find myself wishing you were still here
After you told me all about your dream like it was all you could see
And this girl wouldn't want to get between
A boy and his dream

item.title: 200 OK
item.description:
A JavaScript inspired song that I wrote making it's open mic debut at The Songwriting School of Los Angeles.



LYRICS:

Hello
var Kamie;
Treat me like an object and I won't callback
What's that?
You think I'm funny
I think I'm okay with that

CHORUS:
If you query me about who I am
I'll return enough to make you think
Query me about where I've been
I'll serve up sweet stories
Query me about my plans
I'll return an array of possibilities
You say you want to be a part of them
It's 200 OK with me.

I think too much I'm always mulling it over
You're plagued with anxiety
But when it slips your mind and you focus in real time
I wish you could see what I see

CHORUS

A little bridge nudge followed by an exuberant gush
And a detailed explanation of
What befuddled you for a while
Then a question or a gaze
Asking for my take
That look on your face
I can't help but smile

CHORUS

item.title: What makes employees smile at TowerJazz
item.description:
To celebrate TowerJazz reaching a $1 billion run rate, employees were asked what they like about working at the company and what makes them smile. Here are a few of their answers.

Kamie worked on the concept for this video with Ela Pappo and Felize Richens then shot and edited it for the celebration.

item.title: Since I couldn't fit you in my suitcase...
item.description:
Fill out this form to write yourself here.



A Port Stroll in San Francisco

It has been such a day. We decided we needed fresh air after hours of at a conference so I picked up my and we hit the streets. The aroma made me realize my tummy was talking so I pulled you into a and ordered to go. We talked as we drifted toward Embarcadero and ended up at the port where we sat and watched the boats pass as we ate and discussed complexities of .
